Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Venous stasis ulcers commonly occur on the lower extremities in the area from the midcalf to the ankle; can be single or multiple; are typically irregularly shaped and shallow; and often weep serous fluid. They are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency, such as edema, varicosities, eczematous changes, brown pigmentation from hemosiderin deposition, lipodermatosclerosis (fibrosis of subcutaneous tissue), atrophie blanche (pale plaques of scar tissue), and evidence of healed ulcers. These types of ulcers account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers. Diagnosis is usually made clinically.
